label: A29B40CD12_cF656_227_ae2fg_e3g_b_g-001
title: H$_{3}$PW$_{12}$O$_{40}\cdot$29H$_{2}$O ($H4_{21}$) Structure
comments:
This compound is often colloquially called ``PWA-29.''  On heating some water molecules will disassociate, leaving \href{current_web_home_dir/A27B52CD12_cP184_224_dl_eh3k_a_k-001}{H$_{3}$PW$_{12}$O$_{40}$ $\cdot$ 6H$_{2}$O}, \href{current_web_home_dir/A5B40CD12_cP116_224_bd_e3k_a_k-001}{H$_{3}$PW$_{12}$O$_{40}$ $\cdot$ 5H$_{2}$O} ($H4_{16}$), or \href{current_web_home_dir/A3B40CD12_cP112_224_d_e3k_a_k-001}{H$_{3}$PW$_{12}$O$_{40}$ $\cdot$ 3H$_{2}$O}. 
 The three hydrogen atoms not formally associated with the water molecules are not located.  Presumably they join with some water molecules to form form H$_{3}$O$^+$ ions. 
 Even the exact number and position of the water molecules is uncertain.  (Clark, 1976), studying the related compound H$_{3}$PMo$_{12}$O$_{40}$ $\cdot$ 30H$_{2}$O, states that the composition is approximately 30H$_{2}$O and that ``only six of the water molecules occupy ordered sites.''
